THE TRIUMPHS OF LOVE; OR, Happy Reconciliation. A COMEDY. IN FOUR ACTS.
Written by an American, and a Citizen of Philadelphia.
Acted at the New Theatre PHILADELPHIA.
PHILADELPHIA: PRINTED BY R. FOLWELL, NO. 33, ARCH-STREET. SEPTEMBER 10, 1795.

DIV1.HEAD: THE TRIUMPHS OF LOVE; OR, HAPPY RECONCILIATION,

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. sen.
SP.P: YOU and I, brother, ne∣ver did, or ever will agree on this subject. You know the terms upon which I took your son; I adopted him as my own child, and hold myself responsible for his conduct.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Friend. sen.
SP.P: Little dost thou know his cha∣racter, and much do I repent of putting him under thy direction; it will be the ruin of him, soul and body.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. sen.
SP.P:
'Sdeath, Jacob, what do you mean by such reflections? They are enough to make one quarrel with you outright. After all the expense I have been at, in giving him the first-rate education, don't he possess all those neces∣sary accomplishments which constitute the agree∣able
companion▪—and yet you say I have ruin∣ed him, soul and body.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Friend. sen.
SP.P: What thou doth call accom∣plishments, brother, are what lead him the broad∣way to destruction; there is scarce a night but I hear of his disorderly behaviour; dost thou not think that these reports hurt me, who am the father of the young man?

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. sen.
SP.P: Parents often create themselves unnecessary trouble by being too particular with their children—you multiply all the foibles of your son into vices, and make no allowances for the sprightly sallies of youth; we will see which will turn out the cleverest fellow, him or your primitive son, whom you are bringing up in the straight path. (Ironically.)

SP.SPEAKER: J. Friend. sen.
SP.P: Would that George was like unto Jacob! What a consolation would it be to my mind! It would be a healing comfort, bro∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. sen.
SP.P: And I am sure it would be mortifying to me if George was like unto, Ja∣cob; I mean him for a different sphere in life, and trust some of those days he will make a fi∣gure; I know him—the seeds of greatness are planted in his breast, and time and reflection will make them blossom fair to the world.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Friend. sen.
SP.P: The great danger is, that the rank weeds of vice will overgrow the seeds of virtue: thou hast been too indulgent to him; and where thou hast been most to blame, was in making him too independent of thee.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend.
SP.P:
Brother, these are narrow, contrac∣ted notions; it is destroying every idea of
independence to have a person hanging on one, a wretched dependant; I have placed George in easy circumstances: I know he will be grateful, and make use of his money like a gentleman; come let us go and see Hannah and Rachel.

DIV3.HEAD: Scene.—George Friendly, jun's lodgings.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P: (looking over invitations.) Invi∣tations upon invitations; cards upon cards; I will be with ye ladies and gentlemen: Pleasure thou art my goddess, and I'll pursue thee with unremitting ardour.

DIV3.STAGE: (Enter Jacob Friendly, jun. who gives his bro∣ther a note.)

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P: (Reads.) Very good; tell Ra∣chel I will attend to it. How are all at home, brother Jake?

SP.SPEAKER: J. Friend. jun.
SP.P: Bravely, I'm obliged to thee, brother George.

SP.SPEAKER: Major Manly.
SP.P: Your servant, gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P: Manly, your most obedient.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Friend. jun.
SP.P: Farewell, brother George and friend Manly. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P: There goes the hope of the fa∣mily—daddy's pet.

SP.SPEAKER: Major Manly.
SP.P: He is a good kind of a lad.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P: A sly fellow, depend on't— Harry, methinks you look very brilliant; this has been a grand parade day—a fine sparkling hilted sword—now tell me truly is there not vanity in dangling that fine affair by your side?

SP.SPEAKER: Major Manly.
SP.P:
No, George, not a particle; but I feel a conscious pride in wearing it, for
these reasons:—it has been my trusty friend in the hour of danger; and the first moment I gir∣ded it on this side, I subscribed my name to our glorious independence, which I will support while I have breath.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P: What a Don Quixote in po∣litics! you were always an enthusiast in that way, Harry.

SP.SPEAKER: Major Manly.
SP.P: I glory in being an enthusiast in the cause of liberty and my country; and esteem it the most fortunate circumstance of my life, that I have been instrumental in effecting a re∣volution which has given freedom to millions living, and will secure it to millions yet unborn.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P: A political prophet, too—I hope you will not prove a false one. Our national go∣vernment has its enemies.

SP.SPEAKER: Major Manly.
SP.P: Not a great many: it is the nature of a popular government, like ours, for party-spirit to prevail.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P: Some will tell you it is the life and soul of a republican government: it kept the lamp of liberty burning at Rome a long time, but, unfortunately, extinguished it at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Major Manly.
SP.P:
We have nothing of that kind to fear among us: a great majority of the citi∣zens of the united states are sufficiently enlight∣ened to judge for themselves: they will not be led away or imposed upon by designing men of any description whatever: they, I trust, set a just value upon one of the best constitutions that ever was framed for the government of man. What people on earth, save ourselves, can boast of so free and equal a representation, or of choosing
their chief magistrate? What people under hea∣ven enjoy civil and religious liberty with that pu∣rity we do? With such advantages, and under such a government, how can we but be happy?

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P: There is no doubt but we are, and may continue to be the happiest people on the face of the globe; but let us throw politics aside, and converse about the affairs of the world in general. Have you heard any thing that is wonderful through the day?

SP.SPEAKER: Major Manly.
SP.P: Not a sentence: methinks the town seems very dull.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! dull indeed. Where have you concealed yourself?—Here man—see what a volume of invitations I have: I am engaged to dinners, tea-parties, and balls, for the month to come.

SP.SPEAKER: Major Manly.
SP.P: Really, really, Friendly, you are in great demand;—much in fashion among the belles; I wonder you don't single out one from the fair flock for matrimony.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P:
Matrimony, eh!—no, no, Har∣ry;—as the song goes,
(Sings.) I'll kiss and hug,
And shake a brogue, (dances)
Like a merry, merry rogue,
But hang me if I marry.
No, no, Harry, hang me if I marry—unless I could have a thousand wives.

SP.SPEAKER: Major Manly.
SP.P: What an extravagant rogue thou art! I should think myself supremely blest with one.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P:
Apropos, Major: how do you
come on in that business?—won't father give consent?

SP.SPEAKER: Major Manly.
SP.P: He will not.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P: Run away with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Major Manly.
SP.P: That would be dishonourable.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, honour indeed! do you talk of honour in love matters? Love is not to be restricted.

SP.SPEAKER: Major Manly.
SP.P: Yes, rational love may be; though your sister is the dear and first object of my affections, and one in whom all my earthly happiness is centered, yet such are my no∣tions of honour, that were she to put herself under my protection, I think I could not basely steal her from her parents.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P: Harke, Major, you have ac∣quired much reputation under the banner of Mars, but I am afraid you have too much ho∣nour to make any great figure under that of Venus.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: George, my worthy fellow, how are you? Major, most noble Major, I kiss your hand. The news, gentlemen, tell me at once; I am on the wing in pursuit of the finest girl that ever was viewed by mortal man.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P: The Empress of Russia is dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: And her successor is glad of it; I am off gentlemen. (Exit.)

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P: What an oddity!

SP.SPEAKER: Major Manly.
SP.P: 'Tis a superficial animal. (looks at his watch) I had no conception it was so late. I must be off too; adieu George.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P: Fare you well Harry. (Exit M. Manly.)

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P: Sambo, take this note to Mrs. Soapsuds.

LG.L: Sings. Sweet let me trifle time away,
And taste of love 'ere I grow grey.

SP.SPEAKER: Sambo.
SP.P: Eh, eh, eh, dare he go sing like moc∣key bird. Massa George berry fine young man; berry good to poor foke; he gib great deal mo∣ney away; but he drom rogue for gall; he keep he tings berry close too: he no tell Sambo he secrets; but Sambo be drom cunning for all dat. Now I take dis to missey Sopey Suds; berry well: den missey Sopey Suds gib it to somebody else; Sambo know all about it: how Sambo wish he had a rich quare-toe old uncle, like massa George. he be a drom rogue among fair sex too. (Looks at himself in the glass.) I tink I berry hand∣some fellow:—look much like a gemmen; we negro improbe berry much. (Dances and sings.)

LG.L: Sweete lete me trife time away,
And taste of lub fo I grow grey. Exit.

DIV3.STAGE: Re-enter George Friendly jun. and Trifle.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: I am in love, George, over head and ears, by all that is charming in woman; delu∣ged, inveloped, swallowed up in the great gulf of love;—and with whom do you think?

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P: Why, faith, that it is not easy to divine; but, as I know you are fond of varie∣ty, I should guess it to be with a black damsel.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P:
No, damn it, not quite so strong a sto∣mach; but, by the bye, it is with one of those called people of colour; the sweetest creature
ever my eyes beheld: do you know, Friendly, it is a complection I think superior to all our boasted fair whites and reds: 'tis a fine standing colour: oh, such soft, such sweet, languishing, melting, dissolving looks.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P: Cease, thou rogue, and tell me where she is to be found.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: Such an elegant, such a graceful figure, such dear little feet, such well-turned ancles.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P: No, but prithee, Trifle, where is this yellow piece of perfection to be seen?

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: That is the devil of it: I don't know.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend.
SP.P: And what the devil, have you been talking about all this while?

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: I lost her by the strangest accident that ever happened to man: I will tell you the whole story. As I was addressing her in her own lan∣guage, you know I speak French very well, while I was holding her in conversation, a dog was chasing a monstrous great hog, just out of the wallow,—and what must the damn'd brute do, but run between my legs, and throw me off my centre, to the great mirth of the spectators.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha: it must have been a laughable sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: That was a trifling mortification com∣pared to the loss of her. However, I'll try to fish her out.—

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P: And let me know.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: You are not to be trusted—oh, damn it, I thought I had something to ask you; do you set your face towards Mrs. Peevish's to-morrow night? I am told there is to be a damn'd rout there.—Mrs. Peevish is a sweet woman.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P: She is perfection itself: I was once half in love with that lady myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: It is said you are so yet, George.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friend. jun.
SP.P: Whisper not such a word, Tri∣fle. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: A pack of pickpockets I have about me: every one eating the bread of idleness. Pa∣trick, you Patrick. (Rings a bell in passion.)

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: Shir.

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: Why did you not come before? one must be calling and ringing an hour before you budge.

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: I came as soon as I shaw you ring the bell, shir.

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: You did not, sir: you are such a hea∣vy-heeled fellow that you move like an ele∣phant: Did you attend to the horses last night?

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: Yes, shir: I gave them as much oats as they could ate all night;—and Dick looked as if he would burst this morning he was so fat.

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: Oh, you blundering Irish fool: you have foundered my horses. It is provoking to be plagued with such blockheads. I will send to England for servants that I can depend on: I must go and look after my creatures myself: it is mortifying that people of fortune and fa∣mily should be treated in this way. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P:
(Speaking ironically.) Fortune and family, by my shoul, I know his inshides so well, that if he had all the riches in the world, he
would be a poor man; and as for family, I heard the paple spaking in the kitchen, that he never had a fader, and that his moder was a fish wo∣man, and sold tripes in the market.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Is the old fellow gone?

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: I, and the devil go wid him, I shay.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: You'll get used to him:— don't be disheartened. How do you like this country, Patrick?

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: Why, I like it so well, that if I was once in dare Ireland again, the devil burn me if I would be here.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: That's certain—if you was there you would not be here:—you mean, if you was once in your own country, you would not return to this country.

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: Yes, honey:—that is what I thought I shaid.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: I suppose you have got a sweet-heart there.

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: Upon my shalvation I have not.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Was you ever in love, Patrick?

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: Upon my word I am not quite shar∣tin,—but I think I have some such disorder about me now.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Do you think so?

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: In faith I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: (Eagerly) With whom?—I hope it is with me. (Aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: Why faith, to tell you the honest trute, it is with your dear shelf.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P:
With me, Patrick? You surprize me.
—I am pleased with the declaration: it is a hand∣some good lump of an Irishman. (Aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: You may belave me, when I tell you I love you above all flesh; whene'er I come nare you, I have odd thoughts and strange fail∣ings.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: How do you feel, Patrick?

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: I will tell you, my jewel, and will call all the world to witness the shincerity of my heart: when I come close to you, I fail a trem∣bling all over, and my shoul jumps about so in my body, I am afraid it will tumble out of my mout.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
Patrick.
SP.P: In troth, I would use all my powers by day and night to sharve you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Ah, but we American girls run a great risk in marrying foreigners; perhaps in a year or two, there would be an Irish wife coming to take you from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: I would not lave you for all the wives in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: (Hastily.) Then you are married!

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: The devil burn me if I ever was, and am willing to take my oat of it before all the ists and justices in the whole world.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: What, made you say you would not ave me for all the wives in the world?

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P:
Oh hone, my swate, how you take e alarms for nothing at all at all: what I did
mane was, if I was married to all the women in the world, I would never lave you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Here is our mistress coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: Pray, Jenny dare, let me be upper∣most in your mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Ah, ah, if you behave yourself per∣haps you may. Exeunt severally.

DIV3.HEAD: Scene changes to another apartment.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: Jenny, did you call on mr. Last for my shoes?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Yes ma'm: I have brought them, and he desired me to tell as how he begged you a thousand pardons for not making them sooner.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: It was of no great consequence I suppose he has been hurried. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: (Solus) Considerate soul! most excel∣lent woman! she is worth her weight in gold— the kindest, the best mistress that ever drew the breath of life. Exit.

DIV3.STAGE: Re-enter Mrs. Peevish.—Sets down to her harpsi∣chord.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: Melancholy I will force thee from me. (Plays and sings.)

SP.SPEAKER: R. Friend.
SP.P: Neighbour Peevish, I am come ac∣cording to promise—don't let me interrupt thee—thou knowest how delighted I am with music—I could hear thee the live long day.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: (Rises to meet Rachel Friendly.) —Welcome my dear Miss Friendly, I was waiting with impatience for your agreeable compa∣ny—sit down my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: R. Friendly.
SP.P: I thank thee for thy friendship: and be assured, I find as much pleasure in thy so∣ciety, as thou can possibly have for mine. I should have been here sooner, but for that plaguy creature, Manly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: Ah, ah, ah! The poor major has lost his heart; and don't diguise it from the world, that you have got it.

SP.SPEAKER: R. Friendly.
SP.P: Who! me got his heart? How strange thou dost talk, Betsey Peevish.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: Come, come, Miss; you must not suppose the world does not know you hold the major in chains: treat your captive at least with humanity.

SP.SPEAKER: R. Friendly.
SP.P: Why, to be frank with thee my dear, I confess that he is far from being disa∣greeable to me; but prudence tells me, I must stifle a passion, that if suffered to grow, will be a source of unhappiness to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: Why so, Miss Friendly? are not Mr. Manly's connections respectable: he is in easy circumstances; and as for character, there are few men who stand higher in the opinion of the world.

SP.SPEAKER: R. Friendly.
SP.P: One would suppose he had em∣ployed thee as a counsel, to plead his cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: No: upon my word, I am quite disinterested: what I say upon the occasion, is entirely upon the score of friendship.

SP.SPEAKER: R. Friendly.
SP.P:
I am confident thou art actuated by no other motive. I am sensible of Manly's worth; and was I at liberty to act for myself▪ he would be my choice: but my parents are to be satisfied upon that point; and such are the
inflexible attachments my father has to the rules of our persuasion, that he will not give his con∣sent to my being married in any other way.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: That is a bar, I never thought of.

SP.SPEAKER: R. Friendly.
SP.P: It is a bar I have not the cou∣rage to jump over; tho' it would be into the arms of the man I love.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: Jenny; inform Mr. Peevish, we expect the pleasure of his company to tea.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Yes, Ma'm.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Peevish.
SP.P: Your servant, Miss Friendly; I do not believe there ever was a man in the world so ill used as I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: Poh, poh, my dear; don't let such trifles ruffle your temper.

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: Trifles do you call them? having my horses ruined; my fine greys, that cost me three hundred dollars, by that Irish, buffle-headed blockhead, who told me he understood how to take care of horses.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: Perhaps they are not so injur∣ed as you apprehend: Patrick will take more care in future: he is a good natured obliging creature, as ever we had about the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: Ay, ay—you women always spoil servants.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: Come, my dear—let us have your judgment upon this fresh tea.

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: (Tastes it.) It is horrid stuff; where did you buy it?—what did you give for it?— what scoundrel imposed upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: I bought it from an honest Quaker lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: She is no lady—she is a great cheat: it is bad tea.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: You must not be judge and jury both; and condemn the poor tea, unheard and untried: Now—I think Miss Rachel and myself are the most proper per∣sons, to try, and pass judgment upon the me∣rits or demerits of the said tea. What do you think of it, Miss Friendly?

SP.SPEAKER: R. Friendly.
SP.P: (Tastes it) Why, I think, neigh∣bour Peevish, it is delicious.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: (Tastes it.) And I, also:—It has a most charming flavour.

SP.SPEAKER: R. Friendly.
SP.P: There—thou seest thou hast two to one against thee, friend Peevish.

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: And I think when a man has got the tongues of two women to contend with, it is time for him to decamp:—So, ladies, I leave you to sip your hot water, and talk scandal as long as you please. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: R. Friendly.
SP.P: I did not think thy husband had such an unhappy temper: I thought thou was very happily married.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: Ah! the world is sometimes deceived by appearances.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: Just in the nick of time, ladies:—I have been shooling this hour for a dish of tea.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: Take a seat, Mr. Trifle: You shall be accommodated. (Pours out a dish of tea.)

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P:
(sips.) Dev'lish good faith: a piece
of that dried beef, ma'm—you see I make free, Mrs. Peevish: Freedom is the life and soul of friendship; ha! ha! ha!—I'd thank you for ano∣ther dish, ma'm; (drinks eagerly) another, ma∣dam; (drinks it off,) that was damn'd hot:— Enough, ma'm. Now, ladies, I must feast my eyes. Mrs. Peevish, you look majestic. Miss Friendly, there is an elegant neatness in your dress, that I extremely admire—and, as you are not forbidden fruit, I have a strong inclination to taste you. (Goes to salute her.)

SP.SPEAKER: R. Friendly.
SP.P: I protest thou shall not. (Runs from him.)

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: I protest and swear I will. (Runs after her.)

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: A truce—a truce, Trifle.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: A truce in the moment of victory!— You would make a bad commander in chief, Major. (Kisses her.)

SP.SPEAKER: R. Friendly.
SP.P: I believe, Trifle, thou hast more assurance than all the men in the world put to∣gether.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: You mistake, my dear girl, 'tis confi∣dence—and I find it of infinite use to me: there is no cutting any figure without it: it is that which gives a man a certain consequence in himself. (struts about.) What say you, Major?

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Insignificant puppy. (aside.) As you ask my opinion—I think I had rather be more remarkable for my diffidence, than for my impudence.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: I hope you do not mean to apply that to me, Major?

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Why—will you put the cap on, Tri∣fle?—Mrs. Peevish, I believe I have been so rude as not to enquire after your health: I hope I have the pleasure of seeing you well, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: You are very excusable, Ma∣jor: (looking at him significantly.) I am well, I thank you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: (Rachel Friendly going) —Are you go∣ing, Miss Friendly: Shall I have the pleasure of seeing you home?

SP.SPEAKER: R. Friendly.
SP.P: What a tormentor he is. (Aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Officious coxcomb: (aside) Trifle, you will be so good as to let me have that honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: Ecod, now I think on it; (pulling out his watch) I am, at this very hour, engaged upon business of the utmost importance:—the Major, Miss, will afford himself the supreme felicity of waiting upon you, with all the honours of war. Pardon me—ladies, I am your slave: Harry, I am your's from the highest to the lowest or∣der of men and things. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: R. Friendly.
SP.P: I am glad he is gone. (Aside) Betsey Peevish, I expect thee will soon return this visit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: I will—'ere long. But why is this visit so short?

SP.SPEAKER: R. Friendly.
SP.P: I will give the reasons for it, when I see thee again. Farewell, Betsey.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Madam, your humble servant. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: Adieu—amiable pair:—may heaven smile upon your virtuous loves.

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: Madam, I think you are very defici∣ent in point of respect to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: In what instance, my dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: In what instance?—Why, this even∣ing at tea you made me appear very contempti∣ble:—If you had any sense of gratitude, Ma∣dam, you would behave with more propriety to the man whom you owe all your conse∣quence to.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: Such language, Mr. Peevish, is as cruel as it is unjust:—I have always exerted myself in doing honour to the affairs of your house; and in no way have I been wanting in affection and respect to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: I tell you, Madam, you have forgot yourself. (Exit in a passion.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: Barbarous man:—Ah! why did I sacrifice myself? (Weeps.)

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Don't cry, my dear mistress—don't cry: I heard every word he said to you—and, indeed, Madam, I wonder you don't take up the cudgel; and not suffer him to lord it over you so:—If it was me—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: Hold, Jenny: Don't you pre∣sume to reflect upon your master.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: I won't, Madam, if it is not agreeable to you. O lard—she is the most extraordinary wife I ever heard of: won't abuse her husband herf nor suffer any one else to do it:—If Pa∣trick uses me so, when we are married, if I don't comb his head with a three-legged stool, there is no snakes in Ireland. (Aside.) Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish,
SP.P:
solus. Hard—hard is the lot of helpless women. When young—exposed to the subtile arts of man—who have a thousand ways
to deceive our unwary sex; instead of being our protectors, too, too often become our base destroyers: and when once the marriage knot is ty'd, we become subject to their arbi∣trary and capricious humours. Thus it is with me: allured by the wealth of Mr. Peevish, and prompted by that vanity too common to our sex, of living in all the fashionable parade of life, I gave my hand to the man, that I cannot say I sincerely loved, but yet esteemed; and was in hopes that esteem would have ripened into love:—Alas! I fear it will never take place.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE.—A room in Jacob Friendly sen's House.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter George Friendly, sen. and Jacob Friend∣ly, sen.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, sen.
SP.P: I insist upon it, brother, that parents have not a positive right, in every in∣stance, to cross their children in marriage mat∣ters:—Here are two young people whose affec∣tions are mutual; and who are ready and wil∣ling to pull off their shoes and stockings toge∣ther, and you won't let them.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Friendly, sen.
SP.P: Thou speakest strangely, brother:—If thou wast a parent, thou wouldst not support such sentiments.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, sen.
SP.P:
Yes I would: zounds, what
objection can you have? Is not the man every way upon a footing with your daughter? Is it because he is not one of us. (ironically) I'll maintain it Jacob; and was going to say, it is a dev'lish arbitrary law of your society, that you won't permit a connection with other sects of christians.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Friendly, sen.
SP.P: It is in vain to reason with thee, brother—thou art so violent in what thou dost undertake: our society has had its rules of long standing; which have kept the church to∣gether, from generation to generation.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, sen.
SP.P: Psha, psha—don't tell me a∣bout your generations and generations: you are a virtuous, valuable people; but you should not set yourselves up, in opposition to other people, so much.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Friendly.
SP.P: What aileth thee brother George? —thou looketh as if something troubled thee.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, sen.
SP.P: Ah, ah, ah; yes, sister, I am very much troubled: it vexes me to the heart, to find so much perverseness in your husband: I am sure, if it depended upon you, it would soon be settled—you are a woman of liberality.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Friendly.
SP.P: What is the business?

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, sen.
SP.P: Why, to have your daugh∣ter and the major married, and Jacob won't consent:—Mind; I do not advise them to make a run-away match: but if they do—they will find an asylum at my country seat. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Friendly.
SP.P:
I wish, Jacob, thou wouldst be more accommodating to thy brother—thou knowest he is somewhat hasty, yet has got an
excellent heart:—Consider how much he is the friend of our family.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Friendly, sen.
SP.P: I know it, Hannah—but I cannot be so accommodating as to give up the prerogative of a parent.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Friendly.
SP.P: Indeed, husband, I think thou doth sometimes carry thy prerogative too far: for instance—the other night thou didst for∣bid George from coming to our house.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Friendly, sen.
SP.P: My house shall never be for the reception of profligates.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Friendly.
SP.P: I do not view him as such: but even if he was—remember he is our child.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Friendly, sen.
SP.P: solus. Foolish, and too indul∣gent mothers! it is owing to ye, that children too often take to improper ways:—It is in vain for fathers to precept, while mothers, by their too great indulgencies, counteract all they do.
Rachel, come hither. Have I not always been a kind father to thee?

SP.SPEAKER: R. Friendly.
SP.P: Thou hast been one of the best of parents.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Friendly, sen.
SP.P: Then, why art thou ungrate∣ful?—Why wilt thou wring my old heart?— Why hast thou suffered thy affections to be en∣gaged to a man, so every way a contrast to thy∣self?

SP.SPEAKER: R. Friendly.
SP.P: Ah, me!—What reply shall I make? (Aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: J. Friendly, jun.
SP.P:
Father, there is a Friend
wants to see thee, upon some business of a ve∣ry urgent nature. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: R. Friendly,
SP.P: solus. O love!—O tyrant love! —Thou destroyer of my peace of mind by day, and repose by night: but a little agone, my heart was as free as air—all men were alike to me: now, one object engrosses all my thoughts. In vain I strive to banish him from my affec∣tions, and confine myself to the guidance of my father—whenever I see him, my resolution va∣nishes. Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE.—An apartment in Peevish's House.

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: Patrick, my worthy fellow, you seem to be much improved:—Do you think you can keep a secret?

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: By my shoul, I believe he is taking lave of his rason, be spakes so shensible and shi∣vil. (Aside) Upon my word I can Shir: I will only tell it to Michael O'Gra, my comrade; he and I travelled over sa, in the same ship toge∣ther; he tells me all his sacrets, and I tell him all mine—he is all one as myshelf.

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: But you must not tell anyone.

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: Very well, Shir.

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: I am going out of town. What I want you to do, is—to take notice what gen∣tlemen come here while I am gone—and who comes most frequently: in particular, take no∣tice if young George Friendly comes often.

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: Very well, Shir.

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: Here, Patrick—be attentive. (Gives him money.) Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P:
Now, the devil take me; if I will ei∣ther
kape your money or your sacrets: the mo∣ney I will give to the first poor crater I meet, and the sacret I will give my mistress: I will tell her all, and more too:—The old shinner is jea∣lous; I don't much wonder at it—he must know in his own conshence, he is not shutable for her: O, she is the swatest woman that ever was made—she is sho good and sho kind;— whenever she wants any thing, she will shay— Patrick, I will thank you to do this, or I would be oblaged to you to do that; that makes one do things pleasantly; in fath, I would get up in my slape, any hour in the night, to do her a good turn:—As for him, I have not the laste liking for him; he goes snarling about the house, like an old mastiff; and seems never better plased than when he is in a passion, scoulding us poor sharvants. Upon my con∣shence, he made me sho angry the other day, that if I had not been very much afrade I would have kicked him behind, before his face.—Oh, here is the swate crater. Exit.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Jenny, with a sweeping brush.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Heigho! This love has turned me topsy-turvy; I hardly know what I am about; Patrick is always in my thoughts. In putting water into the kettle, for tea—instead of pump, I put it full of rain water: and this morning, I put on my stockings wrong side out.

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: Jenny, dare, have you shettled the matter wid yourshelf. Will you have me or not?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: I am afraid to trust you, Patrick. (I'll teaze him— aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: Then, as I can't live without you— I'll cut my own troat to shave my wretched life.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: O lard, may be he will—then I shall be made miserable.

LG.L: Sings. O Patrick if I thought you would but be true,
There is no man in this world I'd pre∣fer before you:
But there is a danger in trusting you Irish brogues,
You often turn out to be very great rogues.

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.L: Try me, pray Jenny; try me my swate one do;
Though all may be false, yet Pat will prove true.
I am afraid even when I go to slape on my bed,
When I wake in the morning, I shall find myshelf dead.
So much do I grave after you, thou dare swate American girl;
O try me, pray Jenny, try me—make me but your man:
What more can I do, than do all I can
To plase you, to plase you—thou dare swate American girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Then, Pat, I'll be thine to-morrow-come-two-weeks.

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: I'm struck dumb: I can't spake for joy.

LG.L: Sings. Let us sale with a kiss, (kisses her.)

SP.P: Now America is the best country in the world; and I'll fight for it, while I have an inch of flesh. (Takes her in his arms and runs off.)

DIV3.HEAD: Scene changes to George Friendly jun's Lodgings.
DIV3.STAGE: George Friendly with a letter in his hand— opens and reads.

LETTER.P: "Sir—If you value my happiness and peace of mind, you will no longer visit our house.

DIV3.P: This is mysterious:—Peevish is gone a jour∣ney.— (pauses.) I have it: by all my pleasures past, and joys to come, 'tis a gantlet for an assignation; now for the plan of operation: we soldiers of Venus have a right to assume any shape—Peevish is out of town—she don't want me to appear in the house as young George Friendly. (pauses) I have hit upon the mode—

SP.SPEAKER: Beauchamp.
SP.P: I come, my friend, to bid you farewell; I received some bad news from my island; I am very sorry cruel necessity compel me to leave this country—that it also oblige me leave you, my very dear friend, to whose politeness I am so much in debt.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: My worthy friend, I am dis∣tressed at the occasion that obliges you to leave our country; and lament, that I am to be de∣prived of your society: I hope the accounts you have received, have been exaggerated.

SP.SPEAKER: Beauchamp.
SP.P:
God know: I hope so. I request one thing of you, my dear friend. I left behind one belov'd sister; perhaps she is now on her way
to this country: should she arrive in my ab∣sence, I beg you will give her your protection. Here is one letter for her, and there is her like∣ness.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Rest assured, should she come here, I will render her all the services in my power.

SP.SPEAKER: Beauchamp.
SP.P: I go content: to-morrow I take stage for New-York; there is one ship there which sail direct for the Cape. God bless you, friend.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: May heaven protect you; I hope you will find matters better than you ex∣pect. Are you in want of cash? pray be frank with me; my purse is entirely at your service.

SP.SPEAKER: Beauchamp.
SP.P: You discover your goodness. I have no need, though the obligation is equally impressed: once more, farewell. (Shake hands.) Exit Beauchamp.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Of all the young foreigners I am acquainted with, that youth I most esteem. There is a certain something in the physiog∣nomy and address of some men, that strike at first sight: I had not been an hour in young Beauchamp's company before I became interes∣ted in him; and now feel as perfect a friendship for him, as if I had been acquainted with him for many years.—Now for the likeness of his sister: ha! the most lovely face I ever saw what regular features. (Walks to end fro viewing the likeness).

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Major Manly (unperceived by G. Friendly.)

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: What expression! (Still look∣ing at the picture.)

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: George, I have been weighing the matter well. (Walks in great agitation.)

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: 'Tis a most charming face.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: I have reflected upon the consequen∣ces, and am come to a determination to take your advice.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: What elegant flowing hair.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: What a contest I have had between love and honour, but love has triumphed;— (Still walking agitated) I have resolved, Friendly, to put the question to your sister for an elope∣ment. Why George, don't you hear me speak?

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: (looking round) Oh, Harry, are you there? When did you come in?

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Did you not see me come in?

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Not I, upon my word. Man∣ly, do you know that I am most confoundedly in love?—Young Beauchamp has taken his de∣parture for Cape-Francois, and left in charge with me, his beautiful sister: there is her like∣ness—did you ever see so beautiful a creature?

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: (viewing the likeness) It is a handsome face, but I am acquainted with one much more so—I never heard he had a sister here: where does she lodge?

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P:
Lord, lord, where has my imagination carried me? I am mistaken: she is on her way to this place; but, faith, I am out of my senses: Harry, you have the advantage of me: you are in love with a substance—I only with a shadow. Beauchamp having received unpleasant news from the Cape, set off imme∣diately for New-York, to take shipping for that place: on his departure, he gave me this like∣ness
of his sister, with a letter, requesting, at the same time, if in his absence she should arrive here, I would take her under my protection. Rouze, Manly! damn it, what makes you look so grave? you have lost all your vivacity.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Ah, George, you are a happy fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Happiness was made for man, but he is eternally breaking his limbs over other people's faults, or planting thorns in his own road: well, how do you come on, Hal? Have you made the proposition? try her; I'll engage she will leave father and mother, and cleave unto you. You, that have assisted in lay∣ing the foundation of a great and mighty em∣pire, afraid of a woman! ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: It was the very business I came upon: I have now come to a serious determination of appealing to your sister's affections for a private union.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Bravo, bravo! that will be acting like a soldier. Your hand, Manly: by heaven it joys my heart, that I am to salute you by the name of brother, and that my sister is to be so fortunate, as to fall in with a man of your worth.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: I thank you, my friend: if I should be so fortunate as to gain your sister, I hope I shall prove myself deserving of so valuable an acquisition. I am impatient to be gone, fare∣well. Exit Manly.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P:
solus. Ha, ha, ha! what fools do these females make of us lord-like creatures men! the brave, the gallant Manly, who has
undergone all the fatigues and hardships of war —braved death at the very cannon's mouth— might now be knocked down with a straw; a very slave, a supplicating love-sick man; for my part, I am determined to be free. Now for Mrs. P. The dress will answer very well which I had on in my other night's excursion.
SP.STAGE: (Goes to a closet, takes out a dress, and puts it on.)
SP.L: Sings. And a begging I will go, will go, will go,
And a begging I will go.
SP.P: In this garb I will find my way into Mrs. Pee∣vish's house.

SP.SPEAKER: Sambo.
SP.P: How you cum here? Why you no tump at de door? Dat away you beggar peeple teel in a house when you see nobody, den you tief.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: O, Mr. black man, do not be so hard on a poor unfortunate white man: I have a wife lying at death's door, and three small children down with the small-pox.

SP.SPEAKER: Sambo.
SP.P: You tell true?

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: O, O yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sambo.
SP.P: Where you lib?

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: I live a great distance from here.

SP.SPEAKER: Sambo.
SP.P: Cum here to-morrow: my massa's heart big for poor foke; he gib you someting for you poor wife, and you poor leetel tings.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly. jun.
SP.P: I will come to-morrow. (go∣ing.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sambo.
SP.P:
Tay— (wipes his eyes) poor souls— (takes money out of his pocket) here— (puts it into
G. Friendly, jun's hands) here, take dis: go home quick to you wife and childre, fo fere dey tarve or die fo you get dare.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: I can hardly refrain from embracing him. (Aside.) You are a good black.

SP.SPEAKER: Sambo.
SP.P: I see you safe out of eh door. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish,
SP.P: solus. I have changed my plan: I was afraid to trust that blundering Irishman, and thought it most advisable to assume this beggar's dress: I have hung about my house in order to discover my wife's visitors, and am pretty well convinced of the purity of her con∣duct, and the goodness of her heart: none visi∣ted here but the wretched, and they left the house with tears of joy.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Thus far on my important mission.

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: Ha! there is something here: I will slip into this closet, where I can see and hear all that is going forward. (goes into the closet.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: What are your wants, my friend?

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Now for the wheedling tongue of a Richard, and the impudence of a Sir Harry Wildair. (aside; throws off his dress.) Madam, behold your devoted slave.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: (shrieks) Protect me heaven! where am I?

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: (Takes her in his arms) In the arms of the man who loves you to distraction.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: (Recovers and disengages herself.) Audacious man, stand off.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Come, come, madam; this is carrying the joke too far▪ the note, Mrs. Peevish, you sent me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: Presumptuous coxcomb; to hold you in conversation would be an outrage upon chastity. Begone, ruffian; and in future learn to pay due respect to virtue. (Looking at him with indignation, as she goes off.) Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: So, so, so, so; I have made a pretty hand of it; there is some cursed mistake in this business: well, fortune—legar, I must shew my generalship by making a good retreat. (puts on his dress. As he is going off, Peevish comes out of the closet and pulls off his hat, he in turn, pulls off Peevish's bonnet.)

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: Young rake-hell, have I caught you with intentions to dishonour me?

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Ha! who the devil are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: I'll let you know, scoundrel. (Rings the bell.)

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: 'Sdeath, 'tis Peevish; it is all legerdemain and inchantment. (Aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Madam: Eh, eh, eh, mercy on me, two witches. (Runs out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: 'Tis time for me to make my escape. (Exit hastily.)

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: In the name of shaint Patrick, what are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: Never mind now; run, and seize that person who just now went out.

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: On my life I will not; one bird in the bush is better than two out of the hand. (As I have a shoul to be shaved, it is my old scoundrel of a master; the devil roast me if I will know him, aside.) Besides, it would be unmannerly to lave you with nobody but yourshelf; and as you are a stranger, I sale a kind of duty to provide lodg∣ings for you for fare you might run-away from yourshelf, and get lost in this great shity. (takes hold of him.)

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: Why Patrick, don't you know your master?

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: You auld Beelzebub, my master is at laste a thousand miles from here.

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: I tell you, I am your master; I have changed my mind; I did not go out of town.

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: Arrah, don't be prating to me you ould crater. Enter Constable. Here constable, take this ould woman to the work-house.

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: O lord, O lord, how have I taken myself in. (aside) Constable, I am Mr. Peevish, I am the master of this house. Patrick don't you know my legs. (shews them.) Hell and fu∣ries, what a situation have I reduced myself to?

SP.SPEAKER: Constable.
SP.P: O, 'tis a poor crazy woman, run-away from the hospital: see, her head has been shaved; I will take her back, poor creature.

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: O you devils, you are all combined against me. (Constable takes hold of him.)

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P:
Oh! oh! oh! Murder! murder!
Fire! fire! fire! murder! fire! murder! mur∣der! (As they are carrying him off, Patrick laughs and speaks.) Ha, ha, ha, this is what may be cal∣led shatisfaction. Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: Scene changes to G. Friendly, jun's Lodgings.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: The indignant flash from her eye, shot presumption dead. I have got myself into a pretty scrape: to what lengths has my vanity carried me! by heaven it was ill done; a lady, who is a pattern of virtue; one who al∣ways treated me with the utmost hospitality: what the devil could possess me to put such a vicious construction upon her prudent injunc∣tion. (Walks in agitation) I see now the whole affair. Peevish has become jealous of his wife, without just cause, I am sure. He, in order to come at her supposed inconstancy, has affected to prosecute a journey, but in fact has remain∣ed in town, and assumed the dress of a woman, lurked about the house, to be a ready spy upon the actions of his lady. (pauses) How am I to act in this affair? I must write a penitent letter to Mrs. Peevish; but what the devil shall I say to Peevish? I will go and beg his pardon for the dishonor intended him. If he should require other satisfaction, I shall be rendered extremely unhappy, though not afraid to meet him; yet as I have been the aggressor, it would be adding injury to insult. Peevish is a man of understan∣ding, though of a fretful temper. I hope he will be satisfied with due concessions, and the mat∣ter be hushed: thus I go on sinning and repen∣ting, repenting and sinning. Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE A Garden.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Major Manly, and Rachel Friendly.

SP.SPEAKER: R. Friendly.
SP.P: Henry, thou art fully acquaint∣ed with my sentiments respecting thee; the only obstacle to our union, is the want of my fa∣ther's approbation, and I cannot marry without it.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: But why, my love? (takes her by the hand) be not offended at my calling you by that endearing name: why should there be so blind a submission to the arbitrary mandates of an unreasonable parent? Has there not been a due respect paid to him?

SP.SPEAKER: R. Friendly.
SP.P: Wouldst thou persuade me from my duty? that daughter, who would be want∣ing in gratitude and obedience to her parents, will never make a good wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: I'll run the risk; say that you will be mine. (Kisses her hand.)

SP.SPEAKER: R. Friendly.
SP.P: Ah! Whither wouldst thou lead me?

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: To the altar of Hymen, my charmer, where we may be made the happiest pair in the United States.

SP.SPEAKER: R. Friendly.
SP.P: Stay thee Henry—that would be a step that might involve in it very serious con∣sequences to me. If thou should prove unkind, where should I find a friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P:
And can you, my adorable girl, have a doubt of the lasting sincerity of my love, if the oath or the affirmation of a man of honor will convince you; I declare, in the presence of that being, who knoweth the inmost recesses of all hearts, that neither time nor circumstances
shall abate my affection; and I trust, my dear girl, you will never have cause to repent your partiality for me.

SP.SPEAKER: R. Friendly.
SP.P: Then, to thy honour I resign myself; and hope a little time will reconcile us to my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: (Salutes her.) I am now the happiest man on earth.

SP.SPEAKER: R. Friendly.
SP.P: I see my father coming this way—we must not be seen together. Farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: Here am I, once more in my own house, after pursuing a phantom created by in∣fernal cursed jealousy; I am thoroughly asham∣ed of my behaviour: self conviction, thou re∣former of the human mind; thou glass, in which we see the vileness of our actions, and the impropriety of our conduct: that I have grossly wounded the feelings of an amiable wo∣man, is to me, a matter of keen remorse. Here she comes: I must take every opportunity of convincing her of my penitence.

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: (Salutes her.) I hope, my dear, you have enjoyed a good state of health since I left town?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: This is strange double-dealing. (Bursts into tears.) Mr. Peevish, Mr. Peevish, have I deserved such treatment?

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: My dear love and wife, I am as con∣vinced of your innocence, as I am of my own guilt; and I humbly solicit your pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: Where there is repentance, there should be forgiveness.

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: Do you really forgive me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Peevish.
SP.P: I do, I do: Oh! this is unex∣pected. To be re-instated in your affections, is a piece of good fortune, I did not expect.

SP.SPEAKER: Peevish.
SP.P: Most deserving woman, hencefor∣ward we will live in the habits of love and friendship, and all my future life shall atone for the past. Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE.—The Street.
DIV3.STAGE: Trifle running; G. Friendly, jun. with mask on, pursuing him.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Retournez vous en lache Americain, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, (takes off his mask.) I have had a diverting scene of it. As I was strolling along, I discovered Trifle sneaking about a door; I put this mask on which I sometimes carry about me for my di∣version; pointed my cane at him; spoke loud French, and the fellow took to his heels and run as tho' he had a thousand Indians yelling after him. I'll off to his lodgings, before he get there, in order to have a full laugh at him.

DIV3.HEAD: Scene changes to Trifle's Lodgings.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Ha! I have got here before him.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Trifle, running, with a Sailor's jacket and cap on.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: A curse on all intriguing, I say—O lard, I can scarce breathe—eh, eh, eh.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha—ha, ha, ha—ha, ha, ha—what a metamorphosis. In the name of every thing that is extraordinary, how came you in that dress, Trifle?

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: In this dress?—Why, this dress, George, has been the means of preserving my life. You know, I told you, I would find out the beautiful muste—I did; but had not been there long, before a damn'd great Frenchman, with a nose as big as the man of Strasburgh, made at me, with a sword, as long as himself. I parried him with a small cane-sword I had, till it broke into twenty pieces—then I was obliged to retreat; and if I had not been as nimble as a monkey, he would have pinked me. I ran— he pursued; I slipped into a slop-shop, threw off my hat and fine coat; put on this sailor's jacket and cap, and pushed out of a front-street door; by that means evaded the bloody rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, a narrow escape, upon my word. However, you had this conso∣lation—you did not disgrace the name of an American. You say, you fought with great bra∣very?

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P:
Fought! I had no idea I could han∣dle the sword so well; but a man don't know
what he can do, until he is put to the push. If that Frenchman was here, and had any candor, he would acknowledge I behaved like a valiant man.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: (puts on his mask.) Savez vous le nez. (takes it off.) O Jack! Jack! what a failing thou hast, in deviating so often from the truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: (In a passion.) Sir, Sir, I don't under∣stand such treatment. (Walks about in a pet.)

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Poh—man: don't get into a pet about the matter:—It was quite an acci∣dental affair.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: Damn it, here is somebody coming. I must change my dress. (Pulls off his jacket and cap, and slips on a surtout.)

SP.SPEAKER: Careless.
SP.P: Gentlemen, your most obedient.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Careless, your humble—I have not seen you this age.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: Nor I. (to G. Friendly—0 dem you— aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Careless.
SP.P: Your movements and mine, gentle∣men, are very different. Your time is dissipated in balls, tea, and card parties, &c. for my part, I am fond of my case—and study it before all the fashionable follies of life.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: What materials are you made of, Careless. My happiness consists in balls and routs:—in being in the society of the female world.—What a poor helpless animal man would be, if it was not for lovely, charming woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Careless.
SP.P:
Psha, psha, that is all stuff. I had as
soon have a mill-stone ty'd about my neck, and thrown into the Delaware, as to be obliged to dance attendance after those she affairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: We will have him tried by a court-martial of ladies, for supporting such senti∣ments.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: And condemned and guillo∣tined in one day.

SP.SPEAKER: Careless.
SP.P: Hang me, if I care if it were so. I am almost tired of this world.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly jun.
SP.P: Fye, Careless, fye—rouse and shake yourself. What say you to a social party to-morrow night? I am told Mr. M. has got some excellent claret, and sparkling champaign —there you will have an opportunity of em∣bracing the mistress you love.

SP.SPEAKER: Careless.
SP.P: With all my heart. There is some∣thing substantial in that kind of pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Trifle, you are of the party.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: Oui, Messieurs. (And I'll try if I can't make you dev'lish drunk—so as to make you commit some excess, by way of retaliation—dem you—aside.) I'll be at my post.

SP.SPEAKER: Careless.
SP.P: And I.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: And I—where corks will be drawn instead of daggers. Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: Scene changes to G. Friendly, jun's Lodgings.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sambo. Who goes and views himself in the glass.
Enter G. Friendly, jun. (undiscovered by Sambo.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sambo.
SP.P:
Sambo, what a gal call a pretty fellow. (Sings and dances—tol lol de rel lol—goes again to the glass.) Dis wool of mine will curlee up so, can't get him trait—dat all de fashion among
gemmen. Sambo tink himself handsome. He berry complish'd to; he sing well; he dance well; he play siddle well. Can tink so, so, pretty well. He tink; he berry often tink why he slave to white man? why black foke sold like cow or horse. He tink de great somebody above, no order tings so.—Sometime he tink dis way—he got bess massa in e world. He gib him fine clothes for dress—he gib him plen∣ty money for pend; and for a little while, he tink himself berry happy. Afterwards he tink anoder way. He pose massa George die; den he sold to some oder massa. May be he no use him well. When Sambo tink so, it most broke he heart. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: (solus) Be softened as thou wilt, still, slavery, thy condition is hard. The un∣tutored, pathetic soliloquy of that honest crea∣ture, has more, sensibly affected me, than all I have read, or thought, on that barbarous, ini∣quitous slave-trade—and yet how many thou∣sands of the poorer class of whites are there, whose actual situation are vastly inferior to his: he has no anxious cares for to-morrow, no fa∣mily looking up to him for protection—no duns at his doors. Yet, still, still there is something wanting. It is cruel. It is unjust, for one crea∣ture to hold another in a state of bondage for life. Sambo, thou shalt be free. (Re-enter Sam∣bo.) Sambo, suppose you had your liberty, how would you conduct yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Sambo.
SP.P: Ah, massa George, you no ax Sam∣bo dat for true.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P:
Yes, Sambo, I do; and from
this moment you are free. You may remain with me upon wages, or go where you may think yourself more happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sambo.
SP.P: (In a reverie—then becomes extremely ela∣ted, jumps about; kisses the skirt of his master's coat; —kisses his hand.) O massa George, I feel how I neber feel before. God bress you. (Cries.) I muss go, or my heart burst. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Tell me, ye sensualists, what are all your luxuriant gratifications, compared with the exalted mental sensations of doing a ge∣nerous act? Would to heaven, I could as easy liberate our fellow-citizens, who are slaves in Algiers. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sambo.

LG.L: Now let Sambo dance and sing,
He more happy dan a king.
Now he fly about like bee,

SP.P: When massa George ax me how I like go free, I tink he joke: but when he tell me so for true, it make much water come in my eye for joy. I coud hardly peke a word, and I tink he look like an angel. God bress him. Sambo hope he no be sorry for make him he own massa. I sabe all my wages for buy my Sue free, and make her my wife.

LG.L: He more happy dan a king.

SP.P: He no fear he lose he head. He now citizen Sambo. Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: Scene a room in Major Manly's Lodgings.—(Ma∣jor Manly humming a tune in a sprightly manner.)
DIV3.STAGE: Enter G. Friendly, jun. (Singing and dancing.)

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Tol, lol de lol.—Major, I re∣joice to see you. Harry, my heart is as light as a feather. I have got over that rocky piece of bu∣siness. The dear woman has forgiven me, and Peevish and I are upon the best of terms. As it has happened, good has come out of evil. It was a little unfolding scene, wherein Peevish disco∣vered his wife to be a truly virtuous woman. So, you see I have been the means of promoting her domestic happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly
SP.P: I am glad the affair has ended so well. I hope you will take care for the future how you trespass upon hallowed ground. (Enter Ra∣chel.) Let me have the pleasure of introducing Mrs. Manly to you.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Tantarara, brave boys.— (Jumps about.) Rach. a bride's kiss. (Kisses her.) The Triumphs of Love, Major—ha, ha, ha—soldier, where's your honour? Your hands. (Joins them together.) Long may you live, and be happy!

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: We are sure of your good wishes:— and to complete our happiness, we want those of your worthy father.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Patience, all will come right, by and by. My father no doubt will feaze, and call you naughty names—but you will find powerful friends in my mother, and good uncle.

SP.SPEAKER: R. Manly.
SP.P: I wish, George, thou wouldst go to father's house. Thou certainly dost wrong in staying away.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P:
(Ironically.) I can't find
freedom in going. Thou knowest how peremp∣torily he bid me be gone from his house, because I happened one night to be a little mellow or so, romped with you; hussled Jake; cracked a joke upon my mother; said a smart thing or two to him: In consequence of which, he or∣dered me to depart his dwelling, and not to re∣turn again. When he desires me to return, I will obey.

SP.SPEAKER: R. Manly.
SP.P: It is the duty of children always to give way to their parents.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: I catched the report flying, and was determined to know the truth of it. It is so.— (Runs up to R. Manly.) I always told you, you was a fly rogue. A bride's kiss. (kisses her.) — Major, my gallant fellow, I give you joy. It af∣fords me infinite pleasure, to find that your vic∣torious arms, has encircled the object of your wishes. I hope your union will produce men as brave as the father, and women as beautiful as the mother. Have you heard the news, gentle∣men? There is news arrived, that the people to the westward, are in arms against the laws of government. We are all to turn out: I expect to have the command of a regiment.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: And fight, till your sword is broke into twenty pieces: as you did—

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: Mum—George.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Are you really serious, Trifle?

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: Faith, I am. There has been five ex∣presses come in within this hour.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: At the old trade, Trifle—of stretching?—

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: What does the report say, George? I have had anxious thoughts about those infatua∣ted people.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Only that they have been at∣tacking the revenue officers.—Burning and destroying private property. That is but a tri∣fle for your liberty boys. (I'll put Harry Hotspur in a flame—aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: (Walks in a passion.) Anarchy-boys, rather say. The genuine sons of liberty will ne∣ver disgrace themselves by such a conduct. But will ever be obedient to the laws. (Walking.) A government that is the admiration of the world! That might be the great asylum of the unfor∣tunate, and persecuted of all the earth!—The flattering prospects opening to our view!—To have our national character sullied by a—

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Hold.—These people say, they are deprived of their rights, by being obliged to pay a tax on whiskey.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Very good, very good. So, they are to enjoy all the benefits of government without contributing a single farthing towards its sup∣port! At the very time, too, that its parental arm is extended for their protection. They are ungrateful in the highest degree.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: There are some worthy men in that country.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: I know there are. Men, for whom I have the highest esteem. There are others, again, who take the basest means of acquiring popularity.—Oh! had I but power to lash such scoundrels out of our country!

SP.SPEAKER: R. Manly.
SP.P:
My dear Henry, thou dost seem to
be in much anger. I hope thou wilt not go to fight these wicked people.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: If there is occasion, my love, I will; and should think myself unworthy of being your husband, and being called an American ci∣tizen, if I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: It is but a little human erup∣tion—it will soon be over.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: It is one of those eruptions, George, that if not attended to in due time, there may proceed a fire, that will consume the body poli∣tic.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: How often do these things happen in Europe!

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Why are we eternally confounding our situation with the governments of Europe? There is no comparison. We are a distinct, hea∣ven-favoured people. The very nature of our go∣vernment affords us an opportunity of establish∣ing a national character, superior to any people on the face of the earth.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Mayhap you rate the Ame∣rican character too high:—Human nature is much the same in every age. We are but mor∣tals—and it is the nature of mortals to be rest∣less and dissatisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P:
Never had mortals less cause to com∣plain, than the people of the United States. In no age, nor in any country, was ever human nature in so dignified a state, as in ours.—View our Congress assembled. See the representatives of an extensive empire, clothed with the peo∣ple's power, devising for their general good!— But, there is this to be observed:—It is in vain
for them to legislate, if this fundamental prin∣ciple is not sacredly adhered to:—that, what the majority determine upon, shall be the law of the land. That is the great rock, which our grand democratic republic is built upon. Des∣troy that, and the beautiful fabric will crumble into atoms. If that principle is kept alive, I will be bold to defy either the intrigues of fo∣reign courts, or the conclave machinations of our own citizens, to prevail against it.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: O damn it—I am tired of hearing your politics. George, let us go. You know our engagements. We are to sup to-night at M's. tavern.

SP.SPEAKER: R. Manly.
SP.P: O, brother George—I wish thou wouldst not go so often to taverns. It is time for thee to think of settling thyself.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: And it is time for thee to alter that Quaker tongue; and say Yes Sir, and No Sir: Yes Ma'm, and No Ma'm.—
SP.L: And get the barber to frizzle your hair, tol, lol, &c.
And O how the people will stare, tol, lol de dol, &c.
To see the Quaker turn'd into a fine frizzled lady.

SP.SPEAKER: R. Manly.
SP.P: Thou art too wild, George.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: And thou art too tame Rach. Mayhap you won't always be so. Like most wives, you will get into the habit of scolding by and by. Come, Trifle, let's be gone. The animating Burgundy and sparkling Champagne call us.
Sings. To the copes, to the copes lead away.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: Sings. To the copes, to the copes lead away. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: R. Manly.
SP.P: I wish, brother George would al∣ter his course of life. I am concerned about his evil doings.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: There are few but have their failings, my dear. You will find some in your husband, by and by.

SP.SPEAKER: R. Manly.
SP.P: I don't believe thou hast one.

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: You are all innocence, with respect to George. Some vices he has; but his good qualities vastly outweigh them. He possesses one of the most generous, friendly hearts, that ever was centered in man. If we can but get him engaged in the happy bonds of wedlock, I'll an∣swer for it, he will become a new man.

DIV3.HEAD: Scene changes to Peevish's House.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Patrick, (dressed in a new suit of clothes.)

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P:
Jenny would be for making a gan∣tleman of me. Shays she, Patrick, you must get a new shuit of clothes, and have them made in the fashion. Shays I to her, the devil a farthing has poor Pat to buy them. Then the good shoul inshisted upon rigging me out at her own expence. (looking at himself in a glass.) Upon my shoul, I think Mr. Shars has has made them to fit me very nate.. (struts about.) Fait, I don't know how they do, who are fops and gantle∣man every day. I fale rather unasy in this new-fangled dress. Besides, there seems to be a strange combustible in my head. I hope Mr. Puff has not put some many-fated cra∣ters
in it. All the time the fellow was taring my head, I expected he would pull every hair out. But when I come to look at myshelf in the glass, I found he had put millions more hairs in my head than I had before. (Struts.) Now I am a fine gantleman, I am led to think a little dape. Upon my honesty, I think it is a comical quare world we are oblaged to live in. There is so many downs and ups—so many cross-ways in it, that one don't know which way to look. The oder day, my master and mistress were very much at outs. He was as jealous of her as the de∣vil could make him, and now he is as fond of her as if she was not his wife; and she hangs upon him as if she loved him from the bottom of her shoul. All these things, I shay, puzzles my shen∣ses. Fait, I believe, the best way to have things come right in the end, is to do them wrong in the beginning.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: What an elegant looking man he is now he is dressed. How it delights me to look at him— (aside.) Patrick, I think your clothes fit you very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P:
Arra, my dare Jenny, are you there? Fait, I think so too. I was just admiring my∣shelf, thanks to you, my dare: let me pay a tribute upon your swate lips; (kisses her.) and when I come to be your husband, I'll pay you many fold. But why, my dare, will you push off the business so long? Had we not better become two and one at once? As there are sho many unshartainties in this life—I do not ex∣pect you will decave me, yet I have my fares
for all. I saw English Dick, Mr. Bustle's man, close in wid you, last night. Now, if you were once my wife, you would be quite clare of such rubbish.—Why can't you, my dare shoul, bate the two wakes into to-morrow night, and make it the happiest day of my life. (kisses her.)

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: Stop, Paddy-Whack—you are on my premises. She has promised herself to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: O lard, what shall I do with this fel∣low? (aside.) —'Tis false; I only gave you half a promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: Then I have the best right to her. She has only promised the half or hershelf to you: but she has promished me her whole bo∣dy and shoul, and every part of her. And, shir Dick, if you call me Paddy-Whack again, I'll make you fale the weight of an Irish fist upon your English pate.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: If you are for that kind of work, I can give you the Mendoza tip in a moment. (makes motions to box.)

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Ah! me, what shall I do? they will get to fighting, and the whole house will be in an uproar. (aside.) O, Patrick, don't fight with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P:
Ha,ha, ha, fight wid him: the mushe∣rene is benathe me. For your sake, I will not strike the crater; but I will give him a twir∣ling. (Takes hold of Dick, and gives him a turn— he turns round several times.) That was to the right about. (Gives him another turn.) That was
to the left about. Now march off, before I brake every bone in your skin.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: No I won't— (Speaking loud,) without my wife, my promised wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: O, Dickey, let me beg of you to go away. You make so much noise, I am afraid every moment, that Mr. and Mrs. Peevish will come in. (Was ever poor girl in such a plight? I could poke my head into an augur hole.— aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: I want them to come in. (Speaking lou∣der.) I will make as much noise as ever I can, to expose you; you deceiver.—Hollo, hollo— Paddy-Whack, Paddy-Whack. Irish Pat! Irish Pat!

SP.SPEAKER: Patrick.
SP.P: It is too much for blood and flesh to bear. (Runs after Dick, who falls at his feet—Pa∣trick tumbles over him—Dick gets up.)

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, Paddy-Whack, Paddy-Whack; Irish Pat.—Hallo, hallo. (Runs out— Patrick after him.)

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Oh! Oh! Oh!— (Follows crying.) Pa∣trick, Patrick.

DIV3.HEAD: Scene changes to a Tavern.
DIV3.STAGE: G. Friendly, jun. Careless, and Trifle, at a table singing in chorus.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: And a hunting we will go—and a hunting we will go.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: Damn your singing—push about the bottle. All gone but we three:—heighup. Friendly, I hope you are not flinching?

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P:
Not I. Heighup. I can drink the ocean dry. (Takes the glass, gets up, and reels.) Here's to all generous souls. May they never
know distress. (drinks.) Upon my honor, ac∣cording to the common phrase, I believe I am almost done over.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: (gets up and reels.) O, damn it; you have no head at all. Heighup. I could drink three or four bottles more. What, Careless asleep?

SP.SPEAKER: Careless.
SP.P: (gets up and rubs his eyes.) What the devil is the matter?—heighup. (tumbles on the ta∣ble and throws down the glasses.) Was not that well done? Put them all in the bin, landlord. Heighup.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: I am for a cruize—down town —or battle with the watchmen. Heighup.

SP.SPEAKER: Careless.
SP.P: (gapes and stretches.) I believe I'll moor where I am.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: No casting anchor here, Bob. While you have some sail set, let's get under way. (Pulls Careless along.) Hallo, hallo.

DIV3.HEAD: Scene changes to the Street.—Watchmen crying the hour.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter G. Friendly, jun. Trifle, and Careless, singing in concert.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: And a hunting we will go—and a hunting we will go.

SP.SPEAKER: Watchman.
SP.P: O past twelf o'clock, and a moon∣light morning.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: You are mistaken old man, it rains furiously—heighup. Go back to the watch-house and get your coat.

SP.SPEAKER: Watchman.
SP.P: You are young plackguards, and I'll but you poth all three upon the work-house.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: Take us to the work-house, you old scoundrel; mutter that again, if you dare— heighup.

SP.SPEAKER: Careless.
SP.P: Never mind them, never mind them, Watchman: they are, heighup, both as drunk as David's sow.

SP.SPEAKER: Watchman.
SP.P: Out mitch you; you are all drunk: I'll but every one of you upon the work-house.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: Let me at him, heighup. Let me at the old scoundrel. (makes up to the Watchman— who takes hold of him and throws him down.)

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: (to Careless.) It would be a good piece of fun, to leave Trifle with the watchman. (G. Friendly & Careless going.)

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: Are you going to desert me, gentle∣men? Heighup.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, you are a vali∣ant man; you can defend yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Careless.
SP.P: Take good care of him, Watchman. Heighup. Exit Friendly & Careless.

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: Oh dem ye. I have fell into the pit I have been digging for Friendly, heighup. Mr. Watchman▪ pray Sir, will you be so polite, heighup, as to see me to my lodgings, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Watchman.
SP.P: To the tivel mitch you. It is now Mr. Watchman, and Sir. Pefore, I was an old scoundrel. I will take you home, where you ought to be. Come, get up mitch you.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter George Friendly, sen. and Jacob Friendly, sen.—with fire-buckets.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Friendly, sen.
SP.P: It burned furious, but was soon extinguished. The people, much to their honour, are always very active on such occasions.

SP.SPEAKER: Watchman.
SP.P: Come along mitch you. (Pulls him along.)

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: Murder! Murder!

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, sen.
SP.P: What is all this? Goes up to the watchman. Watchman, don't abuse the poor man.

SP.SPEAKER: Watchman.
SP.P: He has apused me peyond all pea∣ring.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, sen.
SP.P: As I live, it is Trifle!—Why, how came you in this situation, Jack?

SP.SPEAKER: Trifle.
SP.P: Why, Sir, your nephew, George, Careless, and I—heighup; were walking very soberly along, and this old fellow attacked us without mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Watchman.
SP.P: Now, 'tis old fellow again. He tells lies, Master Friendlys: tey were all tree trunk; put he pehaved the worst to me.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, sen.
SP.P: Come, Mr. Watchman, I'll be his bril. See him safe to his lodgings.

SP.SPEAKER: Watchman.
SP.P: Upon your account, Master Friendlys, I will. (Takes Trifle off.)

SP.SPEAKER: J. Friendly. sen.
SP.P: There, thou doth see what kind of company George keeps. That is the way he is constantly debauching and dissipating his time.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Fire! Fire! Heighup. The world is on fire: we shall all be burned! heigh∣up.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Friendly, sen.
SP.P: What do mine eyes behold? Art thou my son Jacob?

SP.SPEAKER: J. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: I am not quite wise enough, heighup, to answer that question.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Friendly, sen.
SP.P: Oh! Heart-breaking fight! Where hast thou been?

SP.SPEAKER: J. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: I'll tell you all about it; heighup. There was Joshua Meek, Jeremiah Sleek, Tom Sly, heighup, and I. Tom Sly and all of us, went to the sign of the goose and grid∣iron; where we had a grand supper, and ex∣cellent, heighup, wine.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, sen.
SP.P: Heighup wine, in truth, ha, ha, ha. Verily, verily, thou art a hopeful youth. I told you, brother, he would flip his bridle some time or other. Yet, take my advice. Let him have more of the rein; dress ; as∣sociate with the girls; go to see a play now and then; and I will engage he will do yet.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Friendly, sen.
SP.P: How have I been deceived in him? Come home, thou knave. Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: Scene changes to a Room in Jacob Friendly sen's House.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Jacob Friendly, sen. and George Friendly, sen.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Friendly, sen.
SP.P: The conduct of that boy has hurt me as much as the undutiful behaviour of my daughter. (Walks to and fro in great passion.) I did once flatter myself, I should enjoy a tran∣quil happiness, in the eve of my life; but my hopes are every way blasted. My daughter sto∣len by a base, infamous villain; robber▪ worst of robbers.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, sen.
SP.P: Where is your christian for∣titude? Patience, man.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Friendly, sen.
SP.P: Talk not to me of pa∣tience. My afflictions are almost as great as Job's.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: You make the very worst of every thing, brother. Remember the old saying: all is not lost which is in danger. You view every thing on the dark side. Now, let me take a look at the light side. It is true, you have been deceived in your younger son; but with prudent management, he may live to be a comfort to you. Your daughter, make the ve∣ry worst of it, has only taken a jump over the pales of your church, and married a man who is an honour to his country, and I am sure, will make her happy. As for George, depend upon it, he will not eventually disgrace you, or dishonour me. Come, let us go to rest. Keep up your spirits, and hope for the best.

DIV3.HEAD: Scene changes to G. Friendly, jun's Lodgings.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sambo, with two candles, reeling & singing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sambo.
SP.P: Sings. Dans sons carmagnole, &c. &c. Liberty and quality for eber and eber. (Puts down one candle.) You tan dere, sir. (puts down the other.) And you tay dere, sir. (Sings.) Li∣berty and quality, for eber and eber. Caesar, Pompey, and I, had drom fine frolic upon a trent of our become free. Caesar massa, forget to put him in a book dat make him free; and de good Quaker foke buy Pompey free. (Reels.) Drom Caesar heart, he make me drink too muth.—Sambo feel berry sick. Eh, eh, eh— house go round like a wholagig. (Holds fast by the scene.)

DIV3.STAGE: Enter G. Friendly, jun. and Careless.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P:
Ha, ha, ha, we have prayed Trifle a devil of a trick. I don't know how you
feel, Careless, but I feel a little sober to what I was.

SP.SPEAKER: Careless.
SP.P: The fumes of the wine have evapo∣rated from me too.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: You will lodge with me to∣night, Bob?

SP.SPEAKER: Careless.
SP.P: With all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Friendly, jun.
SP.P: Sambo.

SP.SPEAKER: Sambo.
